body:
# Armature

Armature is an HTTP routing framework for Crystal.

## Installation

1. Add the dependency to your `shard.yml`:

   ```yaml
   dependencies:
     armature:
       github: jgaskins/armature
   ```

2. Run `shards install`

## Usage

Armature has 2 primary components:

- `Armature::Route`
  - Provides a routing graph by allowing a top-level application to delegate to various child routes based on path segments
  - Provides an [ECR](https://crystal-lang.org/api/1.0.0/ECR.html) rendering macro to render view templates at compile time. View templates are under the `views/` directory in the application root.
  - Provides a missed-match handler (`r.miss`) so you can provide custom 404 handling in a way that's simple and discoverable
- `Armature::Session`
  - If you're using cookie-based authentication, you can use Armature sessions to persist session data between requests
  - Currently the only supported session adapter is `Armature::Session::RedisStore`. The value stored in the cookie is the session id and the data stored in Redis will be the session data serialized into a JSON string.

```crystal
require "armature"
require "armature/redis_session"
require "redis"

class App
  include HTTP::Handler
  include Armature::Route

  def call(context)
    route context do |r, response, session|
      # The `session` can be treated as a key/value object. All JSON-friendly
      # types can be stored and retrieved. The stored session data is saved as
      # JSON and parsed into a `JSON::Any`.
      if current_user_id = session["user_id"]?.try(&.as_i?)
        current_user = UserQuery.new.find_by_id(current_user_id)
      end

      # `render` macro provided by `Armature::Route` renders the given template
      # inside the `views/` directory to the `response` object. This example
      # renders `views/app_header.ecr`.
      #
      # Note: You can render as many templates as you need, allowing for nesting
      # your UI via nested routes.
      render "app_header"
      
      # Root path (all HTTP verbs)
      r.root do
        # Execute the given block only for GET requests
        r.get { render "homepage" }

        # Execute the given block only for POST requests
        r.post do
          # ...
        end
      end

      # Delegate certain paths to other `Armature::Route`s with `on`
      r.on "products" { Products.new.call(context) }

      # Allow for authenticated-only routes
      if current_user
        r.on "notifications" { Notifications.new(current_user).call(context) }
        r.on "cart" { Cart.new(current_user).call(context) }
      end

      # Execute a block if an endpoint has not been reached yet.
      r.miss do
        response.status = :not_found
        render "not_found"
      end

      # Rendering the footer below main app content
      render "app_footer"
    end
  end
end

http = HTTP::Server.new([
  Armature::Session::RedisStore.new(
    # the HTTP cookie name to store the session id in
    key: "app_session",
    # a client for the Redis instance to store session data in
    redis: Redis::Client.from_env("REDIS_URL"),
  ),
  App.new,
])
http.listen 8080
```

Other useful components are:

- `Armature::Form::Helper`
- `Armature::Cache`
- `Armature::Component`

## Contributing

1. Fork it (<https://github.com/jgaskins/armature/fork>)
2. Create your feature branch (`git checkout -b my-new-feature`)
3. Commit your changes (`git commit -am 'Add some feature'`)
4. Push to the branch (`git push origin my-new-feature`)
5. Create a new Pull Request

## Contributors

- [Jamie Gaskins](https://github.com/jgaskins) - creator and maintainer

def.body:
if (__temp_183 = @@cache).nil?
  ::raise(::NilAssertionError.new("Armature.cache cannot be nil"))
else
  __temp_183
end

instance_methods.name: cache
instance_methods.args_string: (key : String, expires_in : Time::Span | Nil, io : IO, & : IO -> ) : Nil
instance_methods.args_html: (key : String, expires_in : Time::Span | Nil, io : IO, & : IO -> ) : Nil

def.name: cache
def.body:
if value = ::Armature.cache[key, as: String]?
  LOG.debug(&.emit("hit", key: key))
  case value
  when String
    io << value
  when Bytes
    io.write(value)
  end
else
  LOG.debug(&.emit("miss", key: key))
  buffer = IO::Memory.new
  writer = IO::MultiWriter.new(io, buffer)
  yield writer.as(IO)
  LOG.debug(&.emit("writing", key: key, entry_size: buffer.bytesize))
  ::Armature.cache.write(key, buffer.to_s, expires_in: expires_in)
end

def.name: fetch
def.body:
begin
  value = self[key, as: T]?
rescue
  return yield
end

if value
  value
else
  value = yield
  write(key, value, expires_in: duration)
  value
end

def.name: fetch_all
def.body:
if keys.empty?
  return [] of T | ::Nil
end

((@redis.mget(keys.map do |key|
  key(key)
end)).as(Array)).map do |value|
  if value
    T.from_msgpack(value.as(String))
  end
end

def.body:
string = String.build do |str|
  value.to_msgpack(str)
end
@redis.set(key(key), string, ex: duration)

def.name: call
authenticity_token_for
def.body:
token = Bytes.new(64)
padded = token + 32
one_time_pad = Random::Secure.random_bytes(32)
if csrf = unwrap_session_value(session["csrf"]?)
  csrf = Base64.decode(csrf)
else
  csrf = generate_authenticity_token!(session)
end

csrf.each_with_index do |byte, index|
  padded[index] = byte ^ one_time_pad[index]
  token[index] = one_time_pad[index]
end

Base64.strict_encode(token)

def.name: unwrap_session_value
def.body:
if value.responds_to?(:"as_s?")
  value.as_s?
else
  value
end

def.name: valid_authenticity_token?
def.body:
if token = form_params["_authenticity_token"]?
else
  return false
end
if csrf = unwrap_session_value(session["csrf"]?)
  csrf = Base64.decode(csrf)
  if csrf.size != 32
    return false
  end
else
  return false
end

token = Base64.decode(token)
if token.size != 64
  return false
end

pad = token[0...32]
challenge = token[32...64]

challenge.each_with_index do |byte, index|
  challenge[index] = byte ^ pad[index]
end

challenge == csrf

request = Request.new(context)

yield request, response, context.session

def.body:
if handled?

end

    yield

end

def.name: is
def.body:
begin
  if handled?
    return
  end

  if (path == "") || (path == "/")
    old_path = original_request.path
    begin
      yield
    ensure
      handled!
    end
  end
ensure
  if old_path
    original_request.path = old_path
  end
end

def.name: is
def.body:
if handled?
  return
end

on(*segments) do |*captures|
  if (path == "") || (path == "/")
    yield(*captures)
    handled!
  end
end

def.name: miss
def.body:
if handled?
  return
end

begin
  yield
ensure
  handled!
end

def.name: on
def.body:
if handled?
  return
end

on(segments) do |captures|
  yield *captures
end

def.name: params
def.body:
if handled?
  return
end
if !params.all? do |param|
  original_request.query_params.has_key?(param)
end
  return
end

begin
  yield params.map do |key|
    original_request.query_params[key]
  end
ensure
  handled!
end

instance_methods.name: write
instance_methods.doc:
Writes the contents of *slice* into this `IO`.

```
io = IO::Memory.new
slice = Bytes.new(4) { |i| ('a'.ord + i).to_u8 }
io.write(slice)
io.to_s # => "abcd"
```

constructors.args_string: (key : String, redis : Redis::Client = Redis::Client.new, expiration : Time::Span | Nil = 2.weeks, log : Log = Log.for("armature.session"))
constructors.args_html: (key : String, redis : Redis::Client = Redis::Client.new, expiration : Time::Span | Nil = 2.weeks, log : Log = Log.for("armature.session"))

def.name: new
def.body:
_ = allocate
_.initialize(key, redis, expiration, log)
if _.responds_to?(:finalize)
  ::GC.add_finalizer(_)
end
_

def.name: call
def.body:
session = Session.new(self, context.request.cookies)
context.session = session

if session_id = context.request.cookies[@key]?.try(&.value)
else
  session_id = UUID.random.to_s
end

call_next(context)

if session.modified? || !session.new?
  context.response.cookies << (HTTP::Cookie.new(@key, session_id, expires: @expiration.try(&.from_now)))
  save("#{@key}-#{session_id}", session.as(Session))
end

def.name: load
def.body:
value = @redis.get(key)
@log.debug(&.emit("GET #{key}", value: value))
value = JSON.parse(value || "{}")
if value.raw.nil?
  value = JSON::Any.new({} of String => JSON::Any)
end

value.as_h

types.name: Template
types.doc:
`Armature::Template` is very similar `ECR` (and is, in fact, derived from it),
but whereas `ECR` is designed to be flexible enough for any kind of output,
`Armature::Template` is specific to HTML. It supports automatic sanitization
for HTML output within `<%= ... %>` blocks, but allows raw output using
`<%== ... %>` blocks — note the `=` vs `==` distinction.
types.summary: Armature::Template is very similar ECR (and is, in fact, derived from it), but whereas ECR is designed to be flexible enough for any kind of output, Armature::Template is specific to HTML.

macros.name: def_to_s
macros.doc:
Defines a `to_s(io)` method whose body is the ECR contained
in *filename*, translated to Crystal code.

```html
# greeting.ecr
Hello <%= @name %>!
```

```
require "armature/template"

class Greeting
  def initialize(@name : String)
  end

  Armature::Template.def_to_s "greeting.ecr"
end

Greeting.new("World").to_s # => "Hello World!"
```

The macro basically translates the text inside the given file
to Crystal code that appends to the IO:

```
class Greeting
  def to_s(io)
    io << "Hello "
    io << @name
    io << '!'
  end
end
```
macros.summary: Defines a to_s(io) method whose body is the ECR contained in filename, translated to Crystal code.

def.name: def_to_s
def.body:
def to_s(__io__ : IO) : Nil
      ::Armature::Template.embed 
{{ filename }}
, "__io__"
    
end

macros.name: embed
macros.doc:
Embeds an ECR file *filename* into the program and appends the content to
an IO in the variable *io_name*.

The generated code is the result of translating the contents of
the ECR file to Crystal, a program that appends to an IO.

```html
# greeting.ecr
Hello <%= name %>!
```

```
require "ecr/macros"

name = "World"

io = IO::Memory.new
Armature::Template.embed "greeting.ecr", io
io.to_s # => "Hello World!"
```

The `Armature::Template.embed` line basically generates this Crystal code:

```
io << "Hello "
HTML.escape name, io
io << '!'
```
macros.summary: Embeds an ECR file filename into the program and appends the content to an IO in the variable io_name.

macros.name: render
macros.doc:
Embeds an ECR file *filename* into the program and renders it to a string.

The generated code is the result of translating the contents of
the ECR file to Crystal, a program that appends to an IO and returns a string.

```html
# greeting.ecr
Hello <%= name %>!
```

```
require "ecr/macros"

name = "World"

rendered = Armature::Template.render "greeting.ecr"
rendered # => "Hello World!"
```

The `Armature::Template.render` basically generates this Crystal code:

```
String.build do |io|
  io << "Hello "
  HTML.escape name, io
  io << '!'
end
```
macros.summary: Embeds an ECR file filename into the program and renders it to a string.

types.name: HTML
types.doc:
`Armature::Template` uses `HTML::SanitizableValue` and `HTML::SafeValue` to
determine whether to perform HTML sanitization on Crystal expressions within
`<%= ... %>` blocks.
types.summary: Armature::Template uses HTML::SanitizableValue and HTML::SafeValue to determine whether to perform HTML sanitization on Crystal expressions within `<%= ...

def.name: to_s
next_token
def.body:
copy_location_info_to_token

case current_char
when '\0'
  @token.type = :EOF
  return @token
when '<'
  if peek_next_char == '%'
    next_char
    next_char

    if current_char == '-'
      @token.suppress_leading = true
      next_char
    else
      if current_char == '|'
        is_output_block = true
        next_char
      else
        @token.suppress_leading = false
      end
    end

    case current_char
    when '='
      next_char
      copy_location_info_to_token
      is_output = true
    when '%'
      next_char
      copy_location_info_to_token
      is_escape = true
    else
      copy_location_info_to_token
    end
    return consume_control(is_output, is_output_block, is_escape)
  end
else
end
consume_string

types.name: HTTP
types.doc:
The HTTP module contains `HTTP::Client`, `HTTP::Server` and `HTTP::WebSocket` implementations.

NOTE: To use `HTTP`, you must explicitly import it with `require "http"`
